A public hearing is opened to allow an opportunity for public to input regarding the 2011-2012 contract opener proposal submitted by the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 at the March 22, 2011, meeting of the Board.  The openers are:
	 
	 
Article 1 Recognition
               
     Article 1.1.2 Non Credit instructors shall be part of the bargaining unit
               
     Article 8 Full-Time Salary, Hire Dates and Seniority Number
               
     Article 8.1 Salary Schedule Increase
     A.  The Union will participate in addressing the current budgetary concerns in the District with
           the following caveats:
          1.  All reductions will be temporary in nature and/or contain contingency language
          2.  All reductions will lead to the following in this order:
               a.  Full time faculty who are transferred being reinstated back to their original positions
                   and categorical non tenured being rehired and/or
               b. Classified and/or adjunct faculty being rehired.
          3.  Any FA, AFT 6157 reductions will not result in management positions being created or
               reinstated
          4.  Before initiating bargaining on any salary reduction, the District must provide the Union
               with the information identifying the vacant positions scheduled for elimination/layoff and
               the full cost of each of those positions (including salary, benefits and mandated benefit
               costs).
     B.  The Union will make specific proposals regarding temporary salary reductions at the
           bargaining table.
	 
Article 9 Adjunct Faculty and Substitutes
	 
     Article 9.1 Salary Schedule Increase-The Union plans on limiting the effect on adjunct
     of any reduction in salary
     Article 9.16 Disbursement of Salary Checks to Adjunct Faculty
     The District shall pay adjunct faculty the same way it pays full-time faculty --10 times a year on
     the last day of the month in equal payments in: August, September, October, November, and
     December for fall semester; and in, January February, March, April and May for spring
     semester
Article 9.18 Scheduling of Adjunct with Seniority Rehire Preference (SRP)
     a.  Once all full time faculty have taken their load and overload, the deans shall send an email
          list of all remaining and available classes to all SRP Adjunct faculty
     b.  The deans shall develop a form (approved by the Negotiation Teams) where adjunct faculty
          with SRP can list their preference for sections.
     c.  Adjunct faculty with SRP shall list up to six sections for which they are available (depending
          on how many sections are offered).
     d.  Adjunct faculty with SRP shall receive their allotted load (33% or 40%) assuming sufficient
          classes in their division
     e.  After each adjunct with SRP has received their allotted load (33% or 40%) the deans shall
          attempt to assign additional sections to adjunct with SRP up to the maximum load before
          offering these sections to adjunct without SRP.
New Article-Ensure SDI election is held and adjunct faculty have to right to have SDI deducted from their paychecks.
	 
Article 11 Calendars-Need calendars for 2012-2013; 2013-4014
	 
Article 12 Workload, Class Size, Class Cancellation
               
     12.3 Faculty Workload
	 
     New Section: Create an enrollment management committee  at each college containing 3
     faculty members- 2 from Academic Senate, 1 from FA, AFT 6157 and equal number of
     management. Key issues would be:
     1.  Classes offered
     2.  Class cancellation
     3.  Class cancellation/addition criteria
	 
Article 17 Benefits
     The Union is evaluating plan design changes and possible dollar contributions to the benefit
     plans to save some money to bring back full time faculty who are transferred to be reinstated
     back to their original positions (categorical non tenured being rehired) and/or laid off classified
     and/or adjunct faculty.
	 
Article 18 Retirement
	 
     New Article 18.5 Offer the Golden Handshake- to encourage retirement of more costly senior
     faculty
	 
Article 24 Reduction in Force
	 
     Article 24.13-Update Faculty Service Area List
	 
Article 31 Completion of Meet and Negotiate
	 
Article 32 Term

Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as, including but not limited to, detailed records relating to: records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period required by any agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
The Bookstore has the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Year-End Inventory Documents from FY 1999-2000 through FY 2002-2003

At the October 12, 2010, Governing Board Meeting, the Board of Trustees reviewed a draft of BP 6304 Travel; and a Board member requested a change to the section related to international travel.
	 
In conformance to BP 2510 Participation in Local Decision Making, the requested change was reviewed by the district's constituency groups. At the October 21, 2010, District Council Meeting, members of the Council discussed the proposed revision and were instructed to review the change with their constituents. At the February 17, 2010, District Council Meeting, the Faculty Association reported their constituents approved the change. However, the Academic Senate President at San Jose City College reported the SJCC Senate did not approve the change because they felt the administrative travel procedures should contain the details, not the policy. At the March 17, 2010, District Council Meeting, the Academic Senate President at Evergreen Valley College reported his constituents voted to not approve the proposed change because of the hardship it would represent to international travelers, such as losing out on reduced airfares. However, the District Council voted 8 yes, 3 no and 2 abstentions to recommend the draft BP 6304 be forwarded to the Board of Trustees for approval. Based on that recommendation, the Chancellor is submitting the draft travel policy for Board approval.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustee approve the draft Travel Policy BP 6304.

The contract with the District’s Independent Auditor, Vavrinek, Trine, Day, & Co., LLP, expired with the completion of the annual audit for fiscal year ending June 30, 2010.  
 
In order to comply with California Education Code 84040, which mandates that the Board of Trustees provide for an annual audit of all funds, books, and accounts of the District in accordance with regulations of the Board of Governors and that the audit shall be made by certified public accountants licensed by the California Board of Accountancy, staff solicited requests for proposals on January 26, 2011, to engage prospective bidders for the fiscal years ending June 30, 2011; June 30, 2012; and June 30, 2013; with the potential for two one-year extensions.
 
Staff identified six potential bidders by seeking recommendations from all California Community College Districts.  The six potential bidders were: Christy White Accountancy Corporation; Matson & Isom; Vicente, Lloyd, & Stutzmann; Nystrom & Co.; Perry-Smith; and Vavrinek, Trine, Day, & Co.
 
Of the six invitations, staff received three proposals for consideration.  The proposals were received from Matson & Isom; Perry-Smith; and Vavrinek, Trine, Day, & Co.  Staff extended an invitation to Perry-Smith and Vavrinek, Trine, Day & Co. based upon the following criteria: capacity to perform (30%), pricing (50%), and reference checks (20%).

items.item_details:
Each year, many community colleges project negative cash flows in some months and must engage in temporary borrowing in order to ensure that funds are available to meet payroll and other expenditures.  Fortunately, for many years, the California Community College League has coordinated an effort to pool the cash needs of these districts by issuing one debt instrument for all districts.  This provides substantial savings in the cost of going to market with short-term debt instruments.  The cost of the Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note to the District is estimated to be between $200,000 and $250,000; however, will be partially offset by the short-term investment earnings that the District will realize while the cash is deposited in the County's investment pool.
	 
The Fiscal Services Department has completed an initial projection of the District's cash flow for Fiscal Year 2011-2012.  In this analysis was factored the projected cost increases to the District along with an assumption that the State will delay the General Apportionment payment for the months of January through June 2012 until October 2012.  It is anticipated that the District will experience a negative cash balance during the first and second quarters of Fiscal Year 2011-2012.  Approval of this resolution will mitigate the deficit cash balance and provide a prudent cash balance (two monthly payrolls) throughout the Fiscal Year 2011-2012.
	 
Attached is the resolution that the Board of Trustees is to adopt in order for the District to participate in the pooled TRANS program.  The initial projection of the District's cash flow for Fiscal Year 2011-2012 is attached separately.

items.item_details:
San Jose/Evergreen Community College District ("District") has desired to enter into a cooperative agreement with the Milpitas Unified School District (“MUSD”) for some time and included in Measure G-2004 the funding to support a center co-located at Milpitas High School ("MHS").  The budget for this facility is currently set at $10,000,000.
  
Collaborative meetings began in August 2009 and have continued with a dedicated cross-functional team from MUSD, MHS, Evergreen Valley College (“EVC”) and the District meeting on a regular basis.  In addition, the District commissioned Maas Companies in June 2010 to develop a “Preliminary Assessment of the Proposed Milpitas Joint-Use Education Center” and in December 2010 “Development Options for the Milpitas Education Center.”  These studies served to inform both the District and MUSD with demographics, potential instructional program enrollment opportunities, development and operational cost projections, and the CPEC guidelines for a joint-use center.  This proposed Memorandum of Understanding is based on current agreements between the District and MUSD after a shared understanding of these studies was reached in January 2011.
		 
This Memorandum of Understanding serves to establish a cooperative relationship between MUSD and SJECCD to implement the University Studies Pilot Program and to establish goals toward developing an EVC Joint-Use Education Center located at MHS.
		 
The University Studies Pilot Program is designed for students who are seniors enrolled at MHS. This program is to provide enrolled students with an opportunity to experience college courses and earn transferable community college credits, which also apply toward graduation requirements.
		 
The program will serve 70 MHS students in 2 cohorts, Fall 2011 and Spring 2012.  EVC will provide the faculty and assistance with admission, concurrent enrollment and registration; MHS will recruit students, provide classrooms and equipment for instruction and ensure students complete appropriate paperwork for admission.
		 
Both institutions agree to have an annual review and evaluation of the pilot program, as well as determine specific actions that can be taken to move toward the EVC Joint-Use Education Center located at MHS in the future as instructional and operational resources become available.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Understanding with Milpitas Unified School District (MUSD) to implement the University Studies Pilot Program located at Milpitas High School and establish goals toward establishing and building an Evergreen Valley College Joint-Use Center at Milpitas High School.

items.item_details:
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  This is a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond with a 55% voter approval threshold and carries the requirement of a citizens bond oversight committee.  One of the areas of focus of this bond is energy efficiency projects with the intention of saving general fund operating costs. In preparation, the District engaged the California Community College League of California in a Memorandum of Understanding ("MOU") to assist with the solicitation and evaluation of solar proposals and the procurement process for solar proposals.  The League's Solar Electric Consulting Services Program provides professional and technical services, is free to the District and covers its costs by exacting a fee from any solar vendor from which the District purchases a solar electric system.  The League's consultant is Clyde Murley.
	 
In anticipation of bond resources availability, in July 2010, the District applied for a reservation for a 849.319 kW system located at Evergreen Valley College, under the California Solar Initiative Program in cooperation with Pacific Gas & Electric ("PGE").  The District successfully reserved an incentive amount of $1,413,594.  The incentive payments will be made to the District on a monthly basis over a 5-year period following system installation, submission, and approval of incentive claim materials.  The incentive payments will be based on the per kWh incentive rate of $0.19 and on the actual energy produced in that time period.  The Proof of Project Milestone due date was March 18, 2011.  This contract with SunPower for $5,596,785 was submitted to PGE on that date, with the notice that the Board of Trustees would entertain the ratification on April 12, 2011.  Ratification by the Board of Trustees will ensure the reservation incentive remain in place.  Project completion is anticipated by January 20, 2012, which is the reservation expiration date.
	 
The installation of the Solar Facilities is exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (“CEQA”) pursuant to Sections 15301, 15303, 15311, and/or 15314 of Title 14, Division 6, Chapter 3, Article 19 of the California Code of Regulations (“CEQA Guidelines”), which categorically exempt the addition of accessory structures to existing facilities, including when such additions neither increase original student capacity nor add additional classrooms. In accordance with Government Code Section 4217.12, the District gave public notice at least two weeks in advance of the public hearing held on April 12, 2011 on the District website and on BoardDocs; and earlier this evening the Board opened and completed the public hearing required pursuant to Government Code Section 4217.12.
	 
The exact site location at Evergreen Valley College for the proposed solar array will be determined with input from the college.  Once ratified by the Board of Trustees, the project will proceed quickly to ensure that the incentive will be preserved and support energy cost relief to the general fund as soon as possible.  The attached financial analysis projects one time savings through receipt of the incentive rebate of $1,413,594 payable over five years, as well as ongoing electricity savings of an estimated $250,000 per year.  Total anticipated operational savings are $8,114,335 over the life of the array. Net cost is $2,417,550.  The savings analysis performed by the League consultant is attached.

items.item_details:
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  This is a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond with a 55% voter approval threshold and carries the requirement of a citizens' bond oversight committee.
 
On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a Program and Construction Management firm to provide Program and Construction Management Services to the colleges and district to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District’s desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District was seeking the services of a Program/Construction Manager to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 Program. The Program Manager shall ensure proper definition and implementation of the work and maximize value to the District and Colleges through effective Program and Construction execution. 
 
Proposals were due to the District on March 11, 2011.  The selection committee consisted of the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services, the College Presidents, and the Interim Controller, with the assistance of a content expert in the construction field.  The District received six proposals and agreed to interview three firms:  Gilbane Building Company, Kitchell, and Parsons.  The unanimous decision was to select Gilbane Building Company based on their experience with community college bond programs, the proposed cost structure, the location of their staff and their supporting office in San Jose, and the quality of their presentation and proposal.
 
This initial contract is for the first year and includes program mobilization, scheduling, strategic program planning for implementation and design, and general program support at the campuses and the District.  The first year contract will be time and materials only at a not to exceed amount of $2,200,000.  The College Presidents and Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services will approve all staffing in advance and direct the work of the program teams. The Program Manager will be working with the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services to ensure overall program accountability and compliance.
 
The contract also contains a unique clause which holds Gilbane accountable for quality assurance:
Quality Assurance Plan Accountability.  The District expects the Program Manager staff to use their collective expertise and long experience in the construction industry to bring to the attention of District staff problems relating to quality in the design and construction of the projects along with recommended solutions.  An amount not to exceed  3% of the Program Manager’s monthly billing will be withheld by the District and released quarterly based on the Program Manager’s successful implementation of their Quality Assurance Program.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the agreement with Gilbane Building Company as the Measure G-2010 Program and Construction Management Firm.

The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  This is a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond with a 55% voter approval threshold and carries the requirement of a citizens' bond oversight committee.
 
On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize an Environmental Impact and CEQA consulting firm to develop the environmental impact reports (EIR) for each college and associated mitigation monitoring program services to support the successful implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects as identified in the Facilities Master Plans.
 
The District issued a request for proposal and two firms responded.  The selection committee consisted of the Vice-Chancellor of Administrative Services, the College Presidents, and a content expert served as advisor.  Both respondents were interviewed.  The committee unanimously selected Impact Sciences due to their experience with community college EIRs, their depth of staffing assigned to the proposal, and the quality of their proposal and presentation.
 
The contract value is $359,200 for both college reports.

Background and Analysis: 
	 
At the June 9, 2009 Board of Trustees meeting, the Board received a report on the CDC Centers.  This report summarized key findings unearthed during an assessment of the CDC Centers at EVC and SJCC.  The EVC CDC was closed, and the site leased to an outside agency.  Several recommendations were made at that time in order to foster the continuance of the CDC program at SJCC.  During the 2009-10 academic year, another review was conducted for SJCC CDC, including feedback from students, employees and the community and a review of fiscal trend data. Research findings included the following:
	 
·       We have insufficient funds to cover all the costs associated with the CDC; the district has had to augment the budget by $150,000 to $300,000.  Future resources remain uncertain, and the outlook is grim for all California Community Colleges.
·       The age and condition of the Center create a less than desirable environment for children and will require significant maintenance with no funding to cover the costs. 
·       The CDC is not ADA compliant, hallways are too narrow.
·       During the Fall, 2010 semester, we received a citation indicating that the Center “could become a risk to the health, safety, or personal rights of children in care if not corrected.”
	 
Therefore, the President recommends closing the facility.  
	 
It is important to note that we are committed to bringing back childcare services to San Jose City College and have begun building a plan for the future of the Center.  The centerpiece of this plan would be the construction of a new, safe, secure building as well as creating a self-support organization through innovative programming and partnerships with our community.
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 041211-4, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.
	 
Identified are (11) positions to eliminate, (11) employees who are to be laid off, and (1) employee who may be bumped due to exercising of seniority rights.

On March 25, 2011 Workforce Institute received notice from work2future (see attached letter) that the WIA funding for the 2011/2012 Program Year is uncertain. The outcome of this uncertainty is either a significant reduction in WIA funding or the complete elimination of WIA funding. Therefore, all positions categorically funded through WIA funding are at risk of being defunded by June 30, 2011.
 
A cautionary action of position elimination needs to be taken in the event the program is defunded.
	 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 041211-5, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.
	 
Identified are (17) positions to eliminate, (17) employees who are to be laid off, and (5) employees who may be bumped due to the exercising of seniority rights.

items.item_details:
Tech Prep education is a significant innovation in the education reform movement in the United States. Tech Prep was given major emphasis in the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act of 1990 and was amended in the School to Work Opportunities Act of 1994.
		 
Tech Prep education is a 4+2, 3+2 or a 2+2 planned sequence of study in a technical field beginning as early as the ninth year of school. The sequence extends through two years of postsecondary occupational education or an apprenticeship program of at least two years following secondary instruction, and culminates in an associate degree or certificate.
		 
Tech Prep is an important school-to-work transition strategy, helping all students make the connection between school and employment.
		 
Information received from the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) in March indicates that the best projection it has for Tech Prep is that the program for 2011-2012 would be called CTE Transitions. CTE Transitions will focus on which postsecondary classes will most effectively help the college recruit and retain secondary students within their CTE programs. Such areas could include career exploration and outreach, articulation renewal, credit by examination, dual and concurrent enrollment and support for work-based learning and internships. 
		 
Funding would approximate the results of merging Tech Prep funding into the base funding and calculating the split with California Department of Education. Using last year’s figures as a guide, CCCCO estimates approximately $43,000 per college to be put out as an allocation to consortia for fiscal year 2011-2012.  Although that sum is smaller than the historic Tech Prep allocation, the grant objectives would also be more circumscribed and focused on community college priorities. This action reduces the current allocation to the campus of $139,800 by $96,800, which will remove funding available for one Classified position. 
		 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 041211-6, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.
		 
Identified is (1) position to eliminate, (1) employee who is to be laid off, and (1) employee who may be bumped due to the exercising of seniority rights.
